title: Chapter 1: Forces and Pressure
subject: Science

questions.question: Which force is responsible for keeping planets in orbit around the Sun?
questions.explanation: Gravitational force between the Sun and planets keeps planets in their orbits.

questions.question: Why do sharp knives cut better than blunt knives?
options: They apply greater pressure due to smaller area
They are made of better material
questions.explanation: Pressure = Force ÷ Area. Sharp knives have smaller contact area, creating greater pressure with the same force.

questions.question: Which of these is a non-contact force?
questions.explanation: Magnetic force can act without direct contact between objects.

questions.question: Why do camels have wide feet?
questions.explanation: Wide feet increase surface area, reducing pressure on soft sand to prevent sinking.

questions.question: What happens to pressure when you stand on one foot instead of two?
questions.explanation: Same weight (force) acts on half the area, so pressure doubles.

questions.question: Why are tractor tires wide and have deep treads?
options: To reduce pressure on soft ground
questions.explanation: Wide tires increase area to reduce pressure on soft ground, preventing sinking. Deep treads increase grip.

questions.question: What force opposes motion when you slide a book across a table?
questions.explanation: Friction opposes relative motion between surfaces in contact.

questions.question: Why does a drawing pin have a sharp point and a large flat head?
options: Sharp point increases pressure for piercing, flat head reduces pressure on finger
Both parts need to be sharp
To make it cheaper to produce
questions.explanation: Sharp point creates high pressure for easy piercing. Flat head distributes force over larger area, reducing pressure on finger.

questions.question: Which statement best describes weight?
options: The amount of matter in an object
The force of gravity on an object
questions.explanation: Weight is the gravitational force acting on an object's mass.

questions.question: Why do snowshoes prevent sinking in snow?
options: They increase surface area to reduce pressure
questions.explanation: Snowshoes spread weight over larger area, reducing pressure on snow.

questions.question: How does a suction cup stick to a smooth surface?
options: Atmospheric pressure pushes it against the surface
It gets hot and melts slightly
questions.explanation: Pushing the cup removes air inside, creating lower pressure. Higher atmospheric pressure outside pushes the cup against the surface.

questions.question: Which force keeps you on the ground and prevents you from floating away?
questions.explanation: Earth's gravitational pull keeps objects, including people, on the ground.

questions.question: Why are heavy trucks fitted with many wheels?
options: To distribute weight and reduce pressure on roads
questions.explanation: More wheels increase contact area with road, reducing pressure to prevent road damage.

questions.question: What is the SI unit for pressure?
questions.explanation: Pressure is measured in pascals (Pa). 1 Pa = 1 N/m².

questions.question: Why do building foundations have large base areas?
questions.explanation: Large foundations distribute building weight over larger area, reducing pressure on soil to prevent sinking.

learning_objectives: Distinguish between contact and non-contact forces
Apply pressure concepts to daily life situations
Recognize the effects of different forces
